Award.AwardTitle: CCI Phase I: Center for the Sustainable Use of Renewable Feedstocks (CenSURF)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Center for the Sustainable Use of Renewable Feedstocks (CenSURF) will address the significant challenge of developing the renewable resources carbon dioxide and lignocellulosic biomass as alternative feedstocks to petrochemicals. Advancing the science and technology for their industrial utilization will be a major intellectual achievement in the chemistry of sustainability. CenSURF researchers will investigate new strategies for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to ethylene and to other C2 compounds, using both molecular and heterogeneous copper-based catalysts. Other team members will probe oxidative disassembly of biopolymer lignin to aromatic monomers, using bio-inspired electrochemical redox mediators (both metal-based, and organic redox shuttles), while a third group will explore a recently-discovered family of catalysts that effect reductive disassembly of lignin and lignocellulose.

New sustainable practices will have a major impact both on the practice of chemistry and on the education of new researchers in the chemical sciences. CenSURF's focus on developing heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts based only on Earth-abundant elements will ensure that new processes are scalable and preserve precious metals and other rare elements for use by future generations. CenSURF will educate graduate and undergraduate students in the principles and practices of sustainability in the chemical sciences, while providing an incubator for innovation in sustainability. Center members will also develop educational and outreach materials in Sustainable Chemistry that will be disseminated widely in schools, through service organizations and via the internet.

The Centers for Chemical Innovation (CCI) Program supports research centers that can address major, long-term fundamental chemical research challenges that have a high probability of both producing transformative research and leading to innovation. These Centers will attract broad scientific and public interest by sharing the results of their approach to this challenging question.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for the Sustainable Use of Renewable Feedstocks (CenSURF) was a Phase I NSF Center for Chemical Innovation (CCI)  funded from September 2012 to June 2017.  The goal was to build and support collaborative research teams to develop sustainable chemistry that can provide benefits to society and the economy while preserving resources for future generations. Experimental and theoretical chemists and engineers from five universities (UC Santa Barbara, UC San Diego, UC Davis, Washington U at St. Louis and Indiana U) made up the core of the center's researchers.  CenSURF's immediate focus was on using Earth-abundant elements to develop innovative, selective, and scalable catalysts to produce platform chemicals from woody biomass-derived waste products of the forest and agricultural industries and from carbon dioxide (CO2).  Biomass and CO2 conversion represent low-carbon footprint pathways to the organic chemicals and liquid fuels needed for modern transportation and materials.

     Lignin is the second most plentiful biopolymer in nature and is a major component of woody biomass. It has the potential to be a very important renewable, non-food, feedstock for producing the organic building blocks that that are industrial synthetic starting materials that are now obtained from petroleum. Because of its chemical complexity, breaking lignin down into these building blocks has proved very challenging, so it has mostly been burned to produce low grade heat. CenSURF researchers were successful in using copper-doped porous metal oxides composed of Earth-abundant elements to disassemble lignin into fragments that could be further processed by electrochemistry into much higher value chemicals. Other CenSURF researchers developed a technique by which this electrochemical processing was coupled to the reduction of CO2 thereby adding more value. These developments may improve the economic viability of utilizing renewable biomass as a replacement for petroleum. Doing so would have much upside potential both for community economic development and for addressubg global issues such as carbon dioxide derived climate change.

      Another key goal of CenSURF was to use outreach and education to project the ethic of sustainability and renewable resource utilization to the greater scientific community and to society as a whole.  Our multi-dimensional approach included fostering an innovative fundamental research and training environment for early career researchers and the development of new educational materials for graduate and undergraduate studies. CenSURF sponsored projects served as the framework for the research training of ~15 graduate students, several postdoctoral fellows and visiting scholars and a large number of undergraduates.  CenSURF also sponsored outreach to K-12 schools and to the larger community to raise awareness of the importance that sustainability has to current and future generations. One of our outreach programs sponsored week-long workshops to better prepare elementary school teachers for teaching the principles and appreciation of the science of sustainability to their students.  We also initiated a similar program directed at zoo education coordinators and are optimistic that such efforts will lead to continuing impact on societal attitudes toward scientific concepts and accomplishments.
